body_html:
Ok, so it seems the problem might be that the wheels are provided for OSX 10.11 only and I have OSX 10.9.5. I don't want to reinstall my OS and break things on my work machine. So I downloaded the OSX 10.11 .whl file from Pypi and renamed it to OSX_10_9. This worked fine, and I was able to install tensorflow.

$ cp ~/Downloads/tensorflow-1.0.0-cp35-cp35m-macosx_10_11_x86_64.whl ~/Downloads/tensorflow-1.0.0-cp35-cp35m-macosx_10_9_x86_64.whl
$ pip install ~/Downloads/tensorflow-1.0.0-cp35-cp35m-macosx_10_9_x86_64.whl

I was able to run the hello world validation, and it just gave me the SSE warning (copied below). I hope the library is safe to run. I would request Pypi wheels to include support for OSX 10.9 and 10.11 as well. Or do you recommend people install from source on these versions?

In [1]: import tensorflow as tf

In [2]: sess = tf.Session()
W tensorflow/core/platform/cpu_feature_guard.cc:45] The TensorFlow library wasn't compiled to use SSE4.1 instructions, but these are available on your machine and could speed up CPU computations.
W tensorflow/core/platform/cpu_feature_guard.cc:45] The TensorFlow library wasn't compiled to use SSE4.2 instructions, but these are available on your machine and could speed up CPU computations.

In [3]: hello = tf.constant('Hello, TensorFlow!')

In [4]: print(sess.run(hello))
b'Hello, TensorFlow!'

body:
Ok, so it seems the problem might be that the wheels are provided for OSX 10.11 only and I have OSX 10.9.5. I don't want to reinstall my OS and break things on my work machine. So I downloaded the OSX 10.11 .whl file from Pypi and renamed it to OSX_10_9. This worked fine, and I was able to install tensorflow. 

```
$ cp ~/Downloads/tensorflow-1.0.0-cp35-cp35m-macosx_10_11_x86_64.whl ~/Downloads/tensorflow-1.0.0-cp35-cp35m-macosx_10_9_x86_64.whl
$ pip install ~/Downloads/tensorflow-1.0.0-cp35-cp35m-macosx_10_9_x86_64.whl 
```
I was able to run the hello world validation, and it just gave me the SSE warning (copied below). I hope the library is safe to run. I would request Pypi wheels to include support for OSX 10.9 and 10.11 as well. Or do you recommend people install from source on these versions?

```
In [1]: import tensorflow as tf

In [2]: sess = tf.Session()
W tensorflow/core/platform/cpu_feature_guard.cc:45] The TensorFlow library wasn't compiled to use SSE4.1 instructions, but these are available on your machine and could speed up CPU computations.
W tensorflow/core/platform/cpu_feature_guard.cc:45] The TensorFlow library wasn't compiled to use SSE4.2 instructions, but these are available on your machine and could speed up CPU computations.

In [3]: hello = tf.constant('Hello, TensorFlow!')

In [4]: print(sess.run(hello))
b'Hello, TensorFlow!'

```
